Hi, everyone.

I'd like to let you know that we've revamped the rules. Please take some time to read them HERE. We felt that it was important to flesh out the scope of the rules to match the needs of an ever-expanding community, as well as the needs of people who help shape the experience within it. In case you're wondering, the actual impact you'll feel from this revamp around the forum will be very little. The majority of you will be able to continue on as you always have. If you have any further questions or suggestions, feel free to use this thread in which to do so. Please keep all comments constructive.

Thanks.

There's no specific "no conspiracies" rule as we felt that alone was too vague. It will still be enforced, though, only now it's covered by other rules and reasons in the list.

Sorry to bump this old thread, but may I humbly suggest that using invisible text in a post be forbidden? I know some people just do it to get around the ten character limit, but some others hide some unpleasantness with it.

I reported a thread the other day that was basically just spam. A list of car stereos and an e-mail address trying to lure people to buy something. The mods did delete it but amusingly I realized there is no rule against spam listed in there.

Rule 2.2i would seem to cover it. Not to mention the catchall disclaimer at the end, which is basically "Even if it's not in the rules, if we don't like it it's still wrong." Which is a great clause, pretty much eliminates rules lawyering.

I also feel that an immediate and permanent ban would be in order for anyone who types in yellow text.

There's no rule against spam because, if everything goes right, you should never see it in the first place. Every accounts' first few posts must be approved by a moderator before they actually go through, and we catch the 'bots then and lock their origins out permanently. But occasionally, we goof and send one through, which seems to be what happened in this case.

And yes, we have a forum rule against roleplaying because some people become overly invested in their fictitious factions, and then the pretend conflicts turn into real feuds between forum members, spilling over into other threads and subforums.
